titleproper.value:
Guide to the Herman F. Mark Collection, 1918-2013

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Lindsay Anderberg

publisher.value: Poly Archives at Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology

addressline: Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2017-08-10T09:37-0400</date>

corpname.value: Poly Archives at Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology

unittitle.value: Guide to the Herman F. Mark Collection, 1918-2013

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The Herman Mark Collection documents the personal and profession life of Herman Francis Mark, the Father of Polymer Science. During his fifty years at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, Mark developed the field of polymer science in the United States, published over 600 articles, and founded the Institute of Polymer Research, the first graduate program of its kind in America.

p.value: Identification of item, date; RG-002: Herman Mark Collection; box number; folder number; Poly Archives & Special Collections at Bern Dibner Library of Science and Technology.
Rodengen, Jeffrey L, and Mickey Murphy. Changing the World: Polytechnic University - - the First 150 Years. Fort Lauderdale, FL: Write Stuff Enterprises, Inc, 2005. Print.

The bulk of the collection relates to Mark's tenure at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn (1940-1990), although some documents and photographs detail his early years in Vienna and his final years in Texas. Mark was a beloved figure at Polytechnic and beyond, as documented by his Polytechnic birthday symposia celebrations and birthday wishes from around the world.

                    <scopecontent id="ref582">
                        <head>Scope and Contents note</head>
                        <p>Professor Mark received birthday letters, cards, and festschrift from Europe, Asia, North America, South America, and the Middle East. Notable well-wishers include President Ronald Reagan, Mayor Ed Koch, and Polytechnic's Bern Dibner.</p>
